[[Image:Daisenji.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The grave of Takeda Nobutora is at Daisenji in [[Kofu, Yamanashi|Kofu]], [[Yamanashi Prefecture|Yamanashi]].]] {{Japanese name|Takeda}} {{nihongo|'''Takeda Nobutora'''|武田 信虎||extra=February 11, 1494 – March 27, 1574}} was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] ''[[daimyo]]'' (feudal lord) who controlled the [[Provinces of Japan|Province]] of [[Kai Province|Kai]], and fought in a number of battles of the [[Sengoku period]].
He was the father of the famous [[Takeda Shingen]],<ref name=Turnbull2>{{Cite book |last=Turnbull |first=Stephen |title=The Samurai Sourcebook |publisher=Cassell & Co. |year=1998 |ISBN=1854095234 |page=208-209}}</ref> who was originally named Harunobu, along with two other sons, [[Takeda Nobushige|Nobushige]] and [[Takeda Nobukado|Nobukado]].
Takeda defeated [[Imagawa Ujichika]] in 1521 at the '''Battle of Iidagawara''', [[Hojo Ujitsuna]] in 1526 at the '''Battle of Nashinokidaira''', [[Suwa Yorishige]] in the 1531 '''Battle of Shiokawa no gawara''', and [[Hiraga Genshin]] in the 1536 [[Battle of Un no Kuchi]] with the aid of his son Shingen.<ref name=Turnbull2/><ref name=Sato>{{Cite book |last=[[Hiroaki Sato|Sato]] |first=Hiroaki |title=Legends of the Samurai |publisher=Overlook Duckworth |year=1995 |ISBN=9781590207307 |page=206-207}}</ref>
During that battle, Nobutora was forced to retreat, but his son Harunobu defeated Hiraga and took the castle. Nobutora nevertheless wished to pass on his domain to [[Takeda Nobushige|Nobushige]], and so Harunobu overthrew his father and exiled him to Suruga. Nobutora didn't return to Shinano until the death of Shingen in 1573, invited by his grandson [[Takeda Katsuyori|Katsuyori]], on that time Nobutora was in his 80's, some reported that even as an old man he still managed to strike fear to people around him.<ref>http://wiki.samurai-archives.com/index.php?title=Takeda_Nobutora</ref>
Nobutora was also a previous owner of a famous sword named "Soza Samonji" (宗三左文字), although he gave that sword to [[Imagawa Yoshimoto]] as a gift to secure an alliance. After Yoshimoto's death at the [[Battle of Okehazama|Okehazama]], the sword came into possession of [[Oda Nobunaga]]. After the [[Incident of Honnoji]], [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]] recovered the sword whom he later gave to [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]] as a gift. The sword is currently a [[Cultural Properties of Japan]]
